thread.title: Longtime Clinton Adviser Doug Band Pays $20 Million for David Rockefeller’s New York Townhouse

author: wsjcom
title: Longtime Clinton Adviser Doug Band Pays $20 Million for David Rockefeller’s New York Townhouse
text:
15 COMMENTS Doug Band , President Bill Clinton’s longtime adviser, has paid $20 million for the Manhattan townhouse of the late banking chief David Rockefeller, according to two people familiar with the transaction.
The house on East 65th Street originally came on the market for $32.5 million last June. It served as the home to Mr. Rockefeller and his wife Peggy for almost seven decades, according to the listing. Mr. Rockefeller, the onetime chief executive of Chase Manhattan Bank and the grandson of industrialist John D. Rockefeller, died last year at the age of 101.
Mr. Rockefeller, the onetime chief executive of Chase Manhattan Bank, died last year at the age of 101. Photo: ASSOCIATED PRESS The house, which has a Colonial Revival-style facade, was built in 1924 and includes 9,777 square feet of space on four levels in addition to a basement, according to the listing. The sitting room and the dining room both overlook the garden. There are eight bedrooms, a library and six staff rooms. The home also has a rear planted garden with silver birch trees and rhododendrons.

He is a founder of Teneo Holdings, a global consultancy. He began his career at the White House in 1995, serving as President Clinton’s adviser from 2002 until 2011 and helping spearhead the Clinton Global Initiative, according to Teneo’s website.
Mary Rutherfurd, Paula Del Nunzio and Leslie Coleman of Brown Harris Stevens had the listing. They declined to comment. Eileen Rockefeller, Mr. Rockefeller’s daughter, could not be immediately reached for comment.
Another property owned by Mr. Rockefeller, in Pocantico Hills, N.Y. , sold for $33 million, 50% above its $22 million asking price, last month.
